pullRequest.body:
give definitions of the class of compactly supported continuous functions and prove basic properties.

Motivation: This class is most natural for the domain of the Riesz-Markov-Kakutani theorem #12290

I copied [Mathlib.Topology.ContinuousFunction.ZeroAtInfty](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/ContinuousFunction/ZeroAtInfty.html#ZeroAtInftyContinuousMap) and am trying to adapt it to compactly supported functions.

nodes.body: I removed all instance names as suggested, except those that are used later. I guess the mathlib convention has been recently changed? (I copied the most of instance names from `ZeroAtInfty`)
I think I addressed all the comments, but to do that, I had to remove all the parts referring to metric. Is this fine? I left conversations with questions open.

I removed the porting note on `HasCompactSupport.is_zero_at_infty`
"-- Porting note: move to src/topology/support.lean once the port is over", as indeed I moved it.

:v: yoh-tanimoto can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

@sgouezel thanks to you for reviewing and guiding me! I learnt a lot in this PR.

@j-loreaux thanks for your time! Please let me know about the naming of `coe_smulc` above.
@yoh-tanimoto, when you're done with the comments, you should set the PR back to `awaiting-review`, as otherwise it doesn't show up on the queue and people won't comment on it.
I thought it was enough to ping Jireh, I set `awaiting-review`.

Let's get this in. Thanks!
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

@yoh-tanimoto Thanks for your hard work on this, and sorry about not reviewing sooner; I've been quite busy. Also, thanks @sgouezel for your reviews!
This looks very good, thanks a lot! Here is a first round of comments on the first half of the file -- don't worry that there are many of them, it's the normal process!

This looks very good. Thanks, and thanks for bearing for me!
bors d+
@yoh-tanimoto Thanks for your hard work on this, and sorry about not reviewing sooner; I've been quite busy. Also, thanks @sgouezel for your reviews!
In your definition, the target space doesn't need to be a metric space, a topological space is enough.

thank you very much for your comments! sorry for my late reply, I will look at them now.
I will change the comment.

It looks like we are missing a lemma saying that a function on a compact space has compact support. Could you add one in the relevant file, and use it here? (Note that your `simp only` and `by exact` are not necessary and can be removed).
By browsing the file names, Topology/ContinuousFunction/Compact.lean seems the right file, although this is actually about `MetricSpace`. I will add the lemma here (for `TopologicalSpace`).

```suggestion
  left_inv f := rfl
  right_inv f := rfl
```
is enough, I think.
You can use the lemma I mentioned above here also.
done.
You don't need the simp attribute on this one, as the previous one will already apply.
ok I will remove the attribute.
I removed `@[simp]` from `mul_apply`.
Don't name your instances in general, unless you have a good reason to do so. Same thing below.
do you mean that I should remove all the names of the instances? As I took the naming from `ZeroAtInfty`, I'm not sure which one is ok.

```suggestion
-- the product of `f : C(, )` and `g : C_c(, )` is in `C_c(, )`
```
In docstring, don't use parentheses around things which are already in quotes, the quotes make it already clear that it's a self-contained unit. Same thing elsewhere in the file.

Instead of registering this for `C(, )`, could you register this for any `ContinuousMapClass`? Even better, could you register this in the more general setting where you have a type gamma acting continuously on beta, for any `ContinuousMapClass` of functions from alpha to gamma?

Could you elaborate what I should do here? I suppose I should define `SMul` between `F` and `G` with `ContinuousMapClass F  ` and `CompactlySupportedContinuousMapClass G  `, but I don't know how to get an object of type `G` from, say, `f : F`, `g : G` and `fun x => (f x) * (g x)`.

About the "action" of `` on ``, do you mean [ContinuousSMul](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/MulAction.html#ContinuousSMul) or something else?

I mean something like
```lean
instance [Zero ] [TopologicalSpace ] [SMulZeroClass  ] [ContinuousSMul  ]
    {F : Type*} [FunLike F  ] [ContinuousMapClass F  ] : SMul F C_c(, ) where
  smul f g :=
    fun x  f x  g x, (map_continuous f).smul g.continuous, g.hasCompactSupport'.smul_left
```
The space on the right of the action is always `C_c(, )`, but the space on the left is any space of continuous functions taking values in a space gamma acting continuously on beta.

Note that for this to work you will need to change the assumptions in the section `DistribMulAction` of the file `Topology.Support`: it should be replaced with the more general
```lean
section SMulZeroClass

variable [TopologicalSpace ] [Zero M] [SMulZeroClass R M]
variable {f :   R} {f' :   M} {x : }

theorem HasCompactSupport.smul_left (hf : HasCompactSupport f') : HasCompactSupport (f  f') := by
  rw [hasCompactSupport_iff_eventuallyEq] at hf 
  exact hf.mono fun x hx => by simp_rw [Pi.smul_apply', hx, Pi.zero_apply, smul_zero]
#align has_compact_support.smul_left HasCompactSupport.smul_left

end SMulZeroClass
```
I see, I just changed as you suggested.
A `AddZeroClass` should be enough, here ane below. For this, can you fix the definition of `HasCompactMulSupport.mul`, requiring only `MulOneClass `?
OK, I will edit Topology/Support.

```suggestion
    Filter.Tendsto f (Filter.cocompact ) ( 0) := by
```

This lemma only needs topological spaces, not uniform spaces, so it's a little bit strange to have it in the section `Uniform`. Also, this lemma means that you can (should?) instantiate a `ZeroAtInftyContinuousMapClass` instance here.
OK, I will remove `UniformSpace` and register an instance of `ZeroAtInftyContinuousMapClass`.

The theorem name should match the statement. So it should be in terms of `HasCompactSupport`. Also, by the naming convention words do start with a lowercase letter. So
```suggestion
theorem hasCompactSupport_of_compactSpace (f : F) :
```
But the statement as written is not good, because you can see that it does not really involve `f`, only its coercion to functions. So there is no gain in having a `FunLike` type here, compared to just stating the result for functions.

Also, for now it's in the namespace `ContinuousMap`, while there is no `ContinuousMap` anywhere around in the statement. Better move it outside of this namespace, and probably to another file (`Mathlib.Topology.Support`, maybe?).
OK, I will move this to `Mathlib.Topology.Support`, changing the name and for `f :   ` and pulling it outside the namespace.

Could you be a little bit more specific in the file-level docstring, with a short introduction saying what the file is about, and then a section introduced with `## Main definitions and results` where you give the name of the main statements, and explain their content? Otherwise, someone just opening the file will need to browse through the whole file to find the name of the statements, and won't have any pointer to help.
I made the description a bit more specific. I think the main points of this file are the definitions and instances, and I wrote so.

Most of the time, it's not needed to specify universes in Lean, unless in very specific situations. So I'd just go for
```suggestion
variable {F    : Type*} [TopologicalSpace ]
```

Same thing, no need to specify the universes.
```suggestion
structure CompactlySupportedContinuousMap (  : Type*) [TopologicalSpace ] [Zero ]
    [TopologicalSpace ] extends ContinuousMap   where
```
I see, I will do this (same here, I followed the way of the old file)

```suggestion
  hasCompactSupport (f : F) : HasCompactSupport f
```
Try to match the symbols. No underscores in `HasCompactSupport`, so no reason why you should introduce one here.

Try to match the symbols. No underscores in HasCompactSupport, so no reason why you should introduce one here.
```suggestion
  hasCompactSupport' : HasCompactSupport toFun
```

```suggestion
variable [CompactSpace ] [One ] [TopologicalSpace ]
```
Using `#where`, you can see which `variable` assumptions are in scope: the type gamma is already declared, as well as the topological space structure on alpha, so you shouldn't declare them again.
I see, thanks for your suggestion.

```suggestion
is a bounded continuous function by `bounded`.
```

```suggestion
When possible, instead of parametrizing results over `f : C_c(, )`,
```

```suggestion
you should parametrize over `{F : Type*} [CompactlySupportedContinuousMapClass F  ] (f : F)`.
```

```suggestion
  hasCompactSupport (f : F) : HasCompactSupport f
```

```suggestion
Whenever `` has the structure of continuous addtive monoid and a compatible topological structure,
```

no need to name your instances, here and below (unless there is a good reason for it, you should remove all names given to instances in this file).
```suggestion
instance [Zero ] : Zero C_c(, ) where
```

The lemma name is not very good, since `hasCompactSupport` does not appear in the name. Instead, it should be `zero_at_infty_of_compactlySupportedContinuousMapClass`. But it's probably worth it to have a standalone lemma, in another file, saying that a function with compact support tends to zero at infinity -- and to use this lemma here to get a very short proof.

In fact, we already have this lemma, `HasCompactSupport.is_zero_at_infty`, so you should just use it to shorten your proof.

[HasCompactSupport.is_zero_at_infty](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/UniformSpace/Compact.html#HasCompactSupport.is_zero_at_infty) assumes` [UniformSpace ]`. I guess this assumption is unnecessary? I wrote a lemma in `Topology/Support`. What should I do with the file `Topology.UniformSpace.Compact`?

Yes, the current assumption if `UniformSpace` is not necessary at all, and the lemma is not in the right file. You should move the lemma to the file `Topology/Support`, but not change its name (and not change its proof, because it already works perfectly fine -- you can see that your version of the proof is a little less efficient).
I did it, except that I did not copy the `#align` lines. I hope that is fine.
You should definitely copy the #align. They make it possible to port automatically Lean 3 projects to Lean 4.

sorry, I didn't know that it needs to be there after being moved. I restored it.
I guess the line `  -- Porting note: move to src/topology/support.lean once the port is over` is not necessary any more.

The full name of this theorem is `CompactlySupportedContinuousMap.bounded`. It's a little bit misleading, as it applies not only to `CompactlySupportedContinuousMap`, but in fact to all `CompactlySupportedContinuousMapClass`. So rather call it `CompactlySupportedContinuousMapClass.bounded`, i.e., don't put the results of this section in the `CompactlySupportedContinuousMap` namespace.

Sorry, I don't know how to do this. Some results are about `F`, but when I move them out of `CompactlySupportedContinuousMap` and under `CompactlySupportedContinuousMapClass`, some notations such as `f.toBCF` are no longer valid. Could you help?
actually, in accordance with your comment below, I removed the section `Metric`, so this is no longer a problem.

```suggestion
lemma _root_.compactlySupportedContinuousMapClass.ofCompact (G : Type*) [FunLike G  ]
```
To avoid the full name `CompactlySupportedContinuousMap.compactlySupportedContinuousMapClass.ofCompact`. Also, make `G` explicit as there is no way to guess it.

You should exit the namespace `CompactlySupportedContinuousMap` for this section, as it has broader application range, and also for the other sections which are about `CompactlySupportedContinuousMapClass`.
I move the section at the end out of `CompactlySupportedContinuousMap`.

```suggestion
```

I don't think that's true: the closure of functions with compact support is rather functions tending to zero at infinity, so `C_c(, )` is not complete. And in fact the topology you're putting here is not the "right" topology on `C_c(, )`, so this metric structure should probably not be registered as an instance. Maybe drop this section from the PR, and come back to it later as there is some design to be carefully thought through?

OK. I made another PR #12629 where I defined a subtype of compactly supported functions. I agree that `C_c` should be given a different topology, maybe the one similar to that for test functions? I removed all the part referring to metric.

```suggestion
theorem hasCompactMulSupport.of_compactSpace (f :   ) :
```
This makes it possible to use dot notation.
this gives the error "to_additive: can't transport hasCompactMulSupport.of_compactSpace to itself.". What should I do?

Sorry, it should have been
```suggestion
theorem HasCompactMulSupport.of_compactSpace (f :   ) :
```

```suggestion
This file contains various instances such as `Add`, `Mul`, `SMul F C_c(, )` when `F` is a class of
continuous functions.
```

```suggestion
`C(, )  C_c(, )`.
```
It's not there any more, right?
yes, sorry, I forgot to remove it as well.

```suggestion
open Topology
```

Can you add here the lemma
```
protected lemma hasCompactSupport (f : C_c(, )) : HasCompactSupport f := f.hasCompactSupport'
```
to make sure that `f.hasCompactSupport` works whenever `f : C_c(, )`?
yes, done.

You are in the namespace `CompactlySupportedContinuousMap`, so you shouldn't put anything on a generic `CompactlySupportedContinuousMapClass` here. Instead, once you are done with everything on `CompactlySupportedContinuousMap` (i.e., close to the end of the file, after the line `end CompactlySupportedContinuousMap`), open the namespace `CompactlySupportedContinuousMapClass` and put it there. A good way to see what needs moving is removing `[FunLike F  ] [CompactlySupportedContinuousMapClass F  ]` from the variables line above.
I move everything referring to `CompactlySupportedContinuousMapClass` under the namespace.

```suggestion
Whenever `` has the structure of continuous additive monoid and a compatible topological structure,
```
These should rather be stated in the general setting of the instance above.
What do you mean by "in the general setting"? They are stated just below the definition of the instance `SMul F C_c(, )`.
Here, these lemmas are stated for `(f : C(, )) (g : C_c(, ))`. They should be for `(f : F) (g : C_c(, ))`, where `F` is like in the instance (and the multiplication will be replaced by , probably).
I see. `coe_smulc` now becomes `(f  g) = fun x => f x  g x`, as this seems to be the only thing that makes sense. Is this useful?
There is no `NormedStarGroup` any more, right?
yes. I remove this and also the comment on C-ring.

```suggestion
/-! ### `C_c` as a functor
```
Do you really need `T2Space` here? I agree that the proof you give needs it, but it's not clear to me if it's necessary.

I tried, there is also an option to assume `[R1Space ]`. I don't know whether this works without any assumption. Which one is better? Or both?

```lean
variable [R1Space ] [Zero ]

/-- Composition of a continuous function with compact support with a cocompact map from an `[R1Space]`
yields another continuous function with compact support. -/
def comp (f : C_c(, )) (g :  co ) : C_c(, ) where
  toContinuousMap := (f : C(, )).comp g
  hasCompactSupport' := by
    simp only [ContinuousMap.toFun_eq_coe, ContinuousMap.coe_comp, ContinuousMap.coe_coe]
    rw [HasCompactSupport]
    have hsuppfc : (Function.support f)  Filter.cocompact  := by
      rw [Filter.mem_cocompact]
      use tsupport f
      constructor
       exact f.2
       simp only [Set.compl_subset_compl, Function.support_subset_iff, ne_eq]
        intro x hx
        push_neg at hx
        exact Set.mem_of_subset_of_mem subset_closure (Function.mem_support.mpr hx)
    apply IsCompact.of_isClosed_subset _ isClosed_closure
    rw [Function.support_comp_eq_preimage]
    obtain K, hK := Filter.mem_cocompact.mp (g.cocompact_tendsto' hsuppfc)
    simp only [ContinuousMap.toFun_eq_coe, CocompactMap.coe_toContinuousMap, Set.preimage_compl,
      Set.compl_subset_compl] at hK
    exact IsCompact.of_isClosed_subset (IsCompact.closure hK.1) isClosed_closure (closure_mono hK.2)
```
Does it work for [R1Space gamma]?

I am not sure. I don't think [IsCompact.isClosed](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Separation.html#IsCompact.isClosed) is valid for `[R1Space X]`, I think a counterexample is any compact R1Space `X`, choosing a point `x : X`, artificially adding a point `y` , considering the space `X  {y}`and declaring that `x` and `y` are indistinguishable. `X` is still compact (any open cover has a finite subcover), but `X` is clearly not closed. So I don't know how to use `[R1Space ]`. Any idea?

In fact there is no need for any separation assumption, since the sets we consider (`tsupport _`) are both compact and closed, so their preimages are both compact and closed also, and we never need that the closure of a compact set is compact. I have pushed a proof.
very nice, thank you!

```suggestion
  neg f := { toFun := -f.1
             continuous_toFun := map_continuous (-f.1)
             hasCompactSupport' := by simpa [HasCompactSupport, tsupport] using f.2 }
```

```suggestion
  sub f g := { toFun := f.1 - g.1
               continuous_toFun := map_continuous (f.1 - g.1)
               hasCompactSupport' := by 
                 simpa [sub_eq_add_neg] using HasCompactSupport.add f.2 (-g).2 }
```
These ones should be in the `CompactlySupportedContinuousMap` section, because the main player here is indeed `C_c(, )`.
I move them back.

```suggestion
lemma of_compactSpace (G : Type*) [FunLike G  ]
```
You're already in the right namespace.
Could you instead write down the instance that `F` is a `ZeroAtInftyContinuousMapClass`?
done.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion hasCompactSupport' := by ```

```suggestion
/-- In a compact space ``, any function has compact support. -/
```

```suggestion
```
No need for the simp attribute here, as this can be deduced by simp from the previous one.

In the next section, you can remove `HasCompactSupport.smul_left'`, as it is superseded by the new version of `HasCompactSupport.smul_left`. Well, don't remove it, instead add a deprecated alias to `HasCompactSupport.smul_left`.
I use `@[deprecated]` and removed the proof, then I leave `#align`. Is this fine?

```suggestion
instance [Zero ] {R : Type*} [SMulZeroClass R ] [ContinuousConstSMul R ] :
    SMul R C_c(, ) :=
  fun r f => r  f, Continuous.const_smul f.continuous r, HasCompactSupport.smul_left f.2
```
No need for `SMulWithZero`, you can do with the weaker `[SMulZeroClass R ]`. Can you fix the next lemmas acordingly?
done.

```suggestion
#align has_compact_support.smul_left' HasCompactSupport.smul_left
```
would be better.

```suggestion
`NonUnitalRing` and `StarRing`.
```

```suggestion
```
I'm not sure it's reasonable to export this in the root namespace.

```suggestion
    {F : Type*} [FunLike F  ] [ContinuousMapClass F  ] (f : F) (g : C_c(, )) (x : ) :
```

```suggestion
/-- A continuous function on a compact space automatically has compact support. -/
```

Can you explain why this is called `coe_smulc`? I couldn't figure it out. What does the `c` mean? Probably adding a docstring about it would be nice. Sorry if this was addressed in earlier reviews; I didn't read them all.
"c" is for Continuous. I thought it would be nice to remember that `SMul` is defined for `ContinuousMapClass F  `, not just `Funlike F  `. But if you don't think it is necessary, I will remove it.
Why are this and the following instance named, but none of the others are? Let's be consistent. The new automated instance naming scheme is pretty good, so maybe let's not name them manually.

When I was removing the instance names and tried to remove the name `instNonUnitalRing`, I remember I got an error, probably the instance name was used below e.g. in `instNonUnitalSeminormedRing` and I didn't know how to define the latter without the former name, so I left it. Now we removed these instances concerning metric, there is no longer problem, so I remove the instance names.
ditto
done.
Can you please add a `TrivialStar` instance under the assumption `[TrivialStar ]`?
done.
I think you copied this from another file and it's no longer applicable.
removed.

```suggestion
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Topology/ContinuousFunction/CompactlySupported) bundle the class of compactly supported continuous functions

source.title: feat(MeasureTheory/Integral): the Riesz-Markov-Kakutani theorem for `Real`-linear functionals

nodes.body: This looks very good, thanks a lot! Here is a first round of comments on the first half of the file -- don't worry that there are many of them, it's the normal process!
I removed all instance names as suggested, except those that are used later. I guess the mathlib convention has been recently changed? (I copied the most of instance names from `ZeroAtInfty`)
I think I addressed all the comments, but to do that, I had to remove all the parts referring to metric. Is this fine? I left conversations with questions open.

I removed the porting note on `HasCompactSupport.is_zero_at_infty`
"-- Porting note: move to src/topology/support.lean once the port is over", as indeed I moved it.

This looks very good. Thanks, and thanks for bearing for me!
